awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Response Diversity and Environmental Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Around the world, societies confront the effects of changing climatic environments. Newspapers report melting polar ice caps, warming lakes and oceans, rising sea levels, ocean acidification, expanding polar vortices, worsening droughts, and intensifying super typhoons. In the face of this, all nations, including the United States, are strategizing how best to evaluate, adjust, and plan. Doing so, however, is complicated by the fact that although change is global, its effects are experienced and responded to locally. How people perceive the environment and its effects on their lives is mediated by culture, language, and geography. Thus effective planning requires understanding not only global forces but also local variability and the response diversity it produces.

The research supported by this award will investigate response diversity in the Philippines, a microcosm of environmental shifts. The Philippines has been struck by a series of super typhoons of increasing frequency and intensity, including Super Typhoon Haiyan in November 2013, the strongest hurricane to hit landfall in recorded human history. The Philippines also faces altered hurricane paths, rising sea levels, sinking islands, mass species extinctions, erratic flooding, and droughts. It is the simultaneity of these developments and the pervasive public awareness that has resulted, all in a single, relatively small arena, that makes the Philippines an illuminating site for investigating responses to environmental change. The research will be carried out by University of California, Los Angeles, doctoral candidate, Bradley Cardozo, under the supervision of Dr. Jessica R. Cattelino. Cardozo will focus on two different groups with contrasting responses to the environmental crisis:  (1) an urban-based political organization, and (2) a rural farming cooperative whose formerly landless peasant members are now experimenting with organic farming and clean energy technologies. Cardozo  will employ a combination of ethnographic research methods, including participant observation in the daily lives and activities of group members; structured and semi-structured interviews; and sustained cultural immersion over the six months to be spent at each site. Using text analysis software, he will catalogue his observations, interviews, and recordings, identify themes, and chart key words and phrases, to delineate the most salient and consequential features of these different responses to common experiences. Cardozo's findings will contribute to improved social scientific understanding of how people's varying perceptions and experiences interact with common events.  Much attention has been focused on the destructive physical effects of the extreme weather phenomena connected to environmental change; this project seeks to document and understand the social and cultural aftermath, as well, and thereby to identify lessons for planners everywhere.

por.por_cntn:
From August 2016 to December 2017, through the generous funding of an NSF-DDRIG, I conducted ethnographic research on the movement for “climate justice” in the Philippines. I worked as a volunteer researcher for the Philippine Movement for Climate Justice (PMCJ), an NGO with its headquarters in Metropolitan Manila and with chapters and partner organizations throughout the country. I sought to understand how these Filipino activists have been responding to the climate crisis in the Philippines by advocating for economic, political, and social policies and practices in the country based on a “climate justice” framework. With more frequent and more intensely monstrous “super typhoons” ravaging the country in recent years, along with alarmingly rising sea levels in the archipelagic country, altered typhoon paths, perilous coral reef bleaching, and more severe flooding and droughts, the Philippines has been classified by climatologists as one of the most vulnerable countries on Earth to the impacts of the global climate crisis. How have Filipinos been proactively responding to this crisis, and what forms of politics, economics, and activism have these responses taken? Informed by anthropological and social scientific methodologies of participant observation, collaborative and “participatory action” research, and structured and semi-structured interviews, I went to PMCJ’s Metro Manila office Monday to Friday, conducting research, drafting reports, attending meetings, and observing actions that the group held in protest against coal power in the Philippines and in favor of renewable energy, among other initiatives. I also attended workshops, hearings and meetings with government agencies and officials, and public educational events, both in Manila and with PMCJ’s chapters and partner organizations in regions like Batangas, Bataan, Cebu, Palawan, and Tacloban. I observed first-hand how PMCJ has been having real impacts at the levels of local and national media discourse, government policy formulation and legislative agendas, business and corporate behavior, and everyday Filipinos’ perceptions and practices.

I saw, for example, how PMCJ and other environmental groups had attained a strong influence on the Philippine government’s Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR) during the tenure of Secretary Gina Lopez, including through Secr. Lopez’s enactment of policies against coal expansion, against destructive mining, and in favor of renewable energy and sustainable environmental projects. By attending press conferences and actions that PMCJ held against coal in the country, I also saw how PMCJ garnered national media coverage promoting the end of fossil fuels and the attainment of 100% clean and renewable energy. In conducting this research, I was able to understand how PMCJ is ensconced within a much more expansive nationally networked coalition of progressive advocacy groups, including Alyansa Tigil Mina (“Alliance to Stop Mining”), 350.org Philippines, Institute for Climate and Sustainable Cities (ICSC), Bukluran ng Manggagawang Pilipino (Union of Filipino Workers), Oriang women’s group, Freedom from Debt Coalition (FDC), and Nuclear-Free Bataan Movement, among many others. I saw how PMCJ and these other groups were able to call on each other for support for different actions and events. Members of these other progressive groups constantly came to PMCJ’s office and vice-versa, thus promoting great camaraderie and solidarity. Through its ensconcement within this larger progressive network, PMCJ was able to mobilize greater numbers of people and resources into its advocacy programs and activities.

This ethnographic project on the climate justice movement in the Philippines contributes to scholarship in the environmental social sciences by demonstrating how PMCJ’s work operates at the intersection of global climate science and postcolonial environmentalism in the Philippines. These Filipino climate justice activists are demonstrating how people in a tropical Southeast Asian and Global South nation like the Philippines can spearhead a path toward national economic development that does not need to follow in the footsteps of the Global North’s dirty trajectory of petroleum and coal-based industrialization. The majority of the world’s countries, including the Philippines, do not have to develop according to models of dirty industrialization that necessarily emit enormous amounts of pollution and greenhouse gases into the atmospheres and oceans of the planet. Rather than massively expanding coal and oil to achieve the goal of national electrification, countries like the Philippines can spearhead a path toward development and prosperity that relies on clean, safe, and renewable energy technologies. However, as the Philippine experience demonstrates, this pathway will only occur through continued popular struggle. Rather than waiting for government policymakers and businesses to reform their behavior, PMCJ and like-minded groups are constantly struggling at all levels of society to attain national economic models that are based on clean energy and social equity. I deeply admire the work that these women and men have been doing to promote climate and environmental justice, and I feel both privileged and humbled to be able to contribute anthropological scholarship about their critical work.
